facts.text: This appeal is directed against the order dated 6.12.2006 passed by the learned Single Judge of the Kerala High Court

issues.text: Whether the verification of the election petition is defective and not in the manner required under Order 6 Rule 15 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908?

anchor.surface_text: the verification of the election petition was number in the manner which is required under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908  hereinafter to be referred to as CPC . Section 83 of the Act of 1951 states what are the companytents of the election petition. Section 83 reads as under Contents of petition.-  1  An election petition  a  shall companytain a companycise statement of the material facts on which the petitioner relies  b  shall set forth full particulars of any companyrupt practice that the petitioner alleges including as full a statement as possible of the names of the parties alleged to have companymitted such companyrupt practice and the date and place of the companymission of each such practice and  c  shall be signed by the petitioner and verified in the manner laid down in the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908  5 of 1908  for the verification of pleadings

issues.text: Whether the affidavit accompanying the election petition in Form No.25 is properly affirmed, certified and discloses source of information as required under Section 83 proviso read with Rule 94A?

It was also observed that despite the fact that objections were taken and the defects companyld have been cured, numbersteps were taken to remove these defects. Hence, learned Single Judge dismissed the election petition as it was number properly affirmed as under Sections 83 85 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951  hereinafter to be referred to as the Act of 1951  read with Rule 94A of the Conduct of Election Rules, 1961  hereinafter to be referred to as the Rules of 1961 .

holdings.text: The verification of the election petition conveys the required meaning despite not using the exact words 'true'; the phrasing 'no part thereof is false and nothing which is relevant has been concealed' is equivalent and sufficient under Order 6 Rule 15 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: After going through the affidavit filed by the appellant and the format of the concluding portion of the affidavit, we fail to appreciate that in what way the verification can be found to be bad except that it has not used the word, true it is expressed in other way, no part thereof is false and nothing which is relevant has been concealed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court compares phrasing to prescribed form, finds substance conveyed same as 'true to knowledge/information', rejects distinction as hypertechnical.

holdings.text: The defect in the affidavit certification by the Notary (placement of 'Before me' after signature) is of very minor nature, bona fide, conveys solemn affirmation, does not go to root of matter.

anchor.surface_text: Here also the defect as pointed out by learned Single Judge was that the appellant had not signed and affirmed in the manner inasmuch as there is no certification of the Notary that it was solemnly affirmed by the appellant before him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examines affidavit format, notes it basically conveys affirmation despite minor placement error, not fatal.

holdings.text: Both defects in verification and affidavit are innocuous, do not go to root, do not warrant dismissal of election petition.

anchor.surface_text: Both the defects which have been pointed out by learned Single Judge were too innocuous to have resulted in dismissal of the election petition on the basis of the preliminary objection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances substance vs form, defects minor not affecting constitution of petition.

holdings.text: Section 86 RPA permits dismissal only for non-compliance with Sections 81, 82, 117; defects under Section 83 do not automatically lead to dismissal under Section 86.

anchor.surface_text: Section 86 says that the High Court shall dismiss the election petition which does not comply with the provisions of Section 81 or Section 82 or Section 117. But no defect of the nature as pointed out by the respondent would entail dismissal of the election petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of S86, distinguishes from S83; relies on precedents like H.D. Revanna.

holdings.text: Even if defects construed as serious, court must issue notice and give opportunity to rectify before dismissing election petition.

anchor.surface_text: These were the defects, even if the Court has construed them to be of serious nature, at least notice should have been issued to the party to rectify the same instead of resorting to dismissal of the election petition at the outset.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principles of natural justice, procedural fairness; appellant bona fide, should allow amendment under CPC O6 R17.

holdings.text: Technical defects in election petition should not result in threshold dismissal; court should direct cure via amendment rather than dismiss.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Single Judge should have given an opportunity to the appellant to amend or cure certain defects pointed out by the Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects respondent's argument on prior opportunity; emphasizes court duty to direct amendment, cites precedents like Murarka Radhey Shyam.

holdings.text: View of Single Judge incorrect; order dismissing petition set aside, matter remitted to High Court for proceeding with election petition.

anchor.surface_text: the view taken by learned Single Judge of the High Court is not correct and we set aside the order dated 6.12.2006 passed by the learned Single Judge in P.No.6 of 2006 and remit this matter back to the High Court of Kerala for proceeding with the election petition of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of above holdings on defects being curable and procedural error.

precedents.citation: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Roop Singh Rathore Ors.  1964 3 SCR 573

anchor.surface_text: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Roop Singh Rathore Ors.  1964 3 SCR 573 . In this case with regard to the defect in the verification, this Court observed as follows We agree with the view expressed by the Election Tribunal and we do number think that the defect in the verification due to inexperience of the Oaths Commissioner is such a fatal defect as to require the dismissal of the election petition.

precedents.case_name: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v Roop Singh Rathore
precedents.cited_proposition: Defect in verification due to inexperience of Oaths Commissioner is not a fatal defect requiring dismissal of election petition
precedents.cited_holding: We agree with the view expressed by the Election Tribunal and we do number think that the defect in the verification due to inexperience of the Oaths Commissioner is such a fatal defect as to require the dismissal of the election petition.

precedents.citation: H.D.Revanna v. G.Puttaswamy Gowda Ors.  1999  2 SCC 217

anchor.surface_text: H.D.Revanna v. G.Puttaswamy Gowda Ors.  1999  2 SCC 217, it was observed as follows The provisions in the Representation of the People Act, 1951 are very specific. Section 86 provides for dismissal of an election petition in limine for number-compliance with Sections 81, 82 and 117.

precedents.case_name: H D Revanna v G Puttaswamy Gowda
precedents.cited_proposition: Non-compliance with Section 83 does not lead to dismissal under Section 86; defect in verification of election petition or affidavit is curable and not fatal
precedents.cited_holding: Significantly, Section 86 does number refer to Section 83 and number-compliance with Section 83 does number lead to dismissal under Section 86. Defect in verification... has been held to be curable and number fatal

precedents.citation: Sardar Harcharan Singh Brar v. Sukh Darshan Singh Ors.  2004  11 SCC 196

anchor.surface_text: Sardar Harcharan Singh Brar v. Sukh Darshan Singh Ors.  2004  11 SCC 196, this Court held as follows In the present case, the grounds of companyrupt practice and the facts necessary to formulate a companyplete cause of action had been stated.

precedents.case_name: Sardar Harcharan Singh Brar v Sukh Darshan Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Deficiency in particulars of corrupt practice not a ground for dismissing election petition at threshold; can direct supply of particulars
precedents.cited_holding: deficiency in particulars companyld number have been a ground for dismissing the petition at the threshold. Only the number-supply of particulars though ordered by the Court companyld have led to either striking off...

precedents.citation: Azhar Hussain v. Rajiv Gandhi 1986 Supp. SCC 315

anchor.surface_text: Azhar Hussain v. Rajiv Gandhi 1986 Supp. SCC 315. There also this Court held that though Section 83 is number mentioned in Section 86, but since the election petition companyld be summarily dismissed under Order 6 Rule 16 and Order 7 Rule 11...

precedents.cited_proposition: Election petition can be summarily dismissed under Order 6 Rule 16 and Order 7 Rule 11 CPC for failure to furnish material facts essential for cause of action
precedents.cited_holding: the election petition companyld be summarily dismissed under Order 6 Rule 16 and Order 7 Rule 11... in case of petitioners failure to furnish any of the material facts and particulars in violation of Section 83...

precedents.citation: Chandrakant Uttam Chodankar v. Dayanand Rayu Mandrakar Ors.  2005  2 SCC 188

anchor.surface_text: Chandrakant Uttam Chodankar v. Dayanand Rayu Mandrakar Ors.  2005  2 SCC 188, it was held that where the defects in companyies were curable number-vital in nature the election petition cannot be dismissed at the threshold...

precedents.case_name: Chandrakant Uttam Chodankar v Dayanand Rayu Mandrakar
precedents.cited_proposition: Curable non-vital defects in copies do not warrant dismissal of election petition at threshold for non-compliance with Section 81(3)
precedents.cited_holding: where the defects in companyies were curable number-vital in nature the election petition cannot be dismissed at the threshold for number-compliance with Section 81 3  on the basis of such defects.

precedents.citation: Ram Prasad Sarma v. Mani Kumar Subba Ors. Etc.  2003  1 SCC 289

anchor.surface_text: Ram Prasad Sarma v. Mani Kumar Subba Ors. Etc.  2003  1 SCC 289, it was held that verification in support of the allegations of companyrupt practice accompanying the petition by Oath Commissioner was number integral part of the petition.

precedents.case_name: Ram Prasad Sarma v Mani Kumar Subba
precedents.cited_proposition: Absence of stamp and name of Oath Commissioner in affidavit is minor defect, not material deviation, election petition not liable to dismissal
precedents.cited_holding: Mere absence of the stamp and name of Oath Commissioner in the true companyy of the affidavit would number amount to vital or material deviation... the election petition is number liable to be dismissed at the threshold.

precedents.citation: R.P.Moidutty v. P.T.Kunju Mohammad Anr.  2000  1 SCC 481

anchor.surface_text: R.P.Moidutty v. P.T.Kunju Mohammad Anr.  2000  1 SCC 481 their Lordships have expressed that heavy onus lies on the election petitioner...

precedents.case_name: R P Moidutty v P T Kunju Mohammad
precedents.cited_proposition: Defect in verification is not fatal and can be cured; however, if petitioner persists without rectification after objection, petition cannot be tried
precedents.cited_holding: the defect of verification is number fatal to the petition, it can be cured... However, the defect in verification was pointed out... the petitioner persisted in pursuing the petition without proper verification which the petitioner should number have been permitted to do.

anchor.surface_text: As observed by the Supreme Court in A.Sapa v. Singora the object of requiring verification of an election petition is to clearly fix the responsibility for the averments and allegations in the petition on the person signing the verification...

precedents.cited_proposition: Object of verification is to fix responsibility and discourage wild allegations; defect is curable

precedents.case_name: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v Roop Singh Rathore

anchor.surface_text: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Roop Singh Rathore and A.S.Subbaraj v. M. Muthiah  .
